string.text: You are affected by PTSD from watching your closest friend and former travelling companion get torn to shreds by a Whirligig Anomaly.
You have grown fond of cooking and eating mutant meat during your time in the Zone, and know plenty of recipes for preparing mutants.

You have crippling gambling debt. While deployed in the Zone you are constantly on the lookout for any off-the-record activity that might earn you some money that could go towards paying off your debt.
You are obsessed with pushing further north, and want to one day explore the Chernobyl Reactor.
You have recently turned to Christianity and Jesus after having done and experienced horrible things in the Zone.
You are long divorced and asked for an assignment in the Zone to forget about your ex-wife, who left you years ago but whom you still can't get over.
You regret coming to the Zone and long to escape back out to the normal world.

You found an old worn copy of 'The Way of Zen' by Alan Watts. In a desperate attempt to cope with the stress of the Zone you have turned to it, hoping Zen Buddhism might give you some sort of peace. You don't have any deeper understanding but you tell yourself muttering random quotes from the book helps somehow.
You are a guilt-ridden about all the horrible things you have done on previous assingments as a Black Ops agent.
You are a habitual gambling addict. You try to engage people you meet in the Zone in casual wagers whenever the opportunity arises.
You used to be an operative for the US Special Forces.

You came to the Zone because your girlfriend aborted your baby. You wanted to keep it and start a family, and the conflict ruined your relationship. You asked for a foreign deployment to run from the silence.
You kept your habit from the outside world of writing figures in a small black leatherbound accounts book: artifacts sold, bullets spent, cigarettes borrowed, people killed.
You used to be a US Black Ops agent for the NSA. You have participated in committing numerous war crimes.
Your family on the outside thinks you're working on an oil rig. You are always on the lookout for photos and mementos to send them that can keep up the lie.
You used to sell seeds at a market in Austin in Texas when you grew up. You still use seed envelopes to sort and store spare bullets.
Your father was a locksmith, and taught you his trade growing up. You still pick random padlocks and doors you come across to keep up the skill.
You keep a cracked snowglobe of your Minnesota hometown in an inside pocket. You take it out and shake it whenever the homesickness becomes too great.

You tried to start a family despite your line of work. You were never able to tell your wife exactly what kind of 'government work' it is you do, and one night she took the kids and left saying 'choose either us or your work'. You're still torn up about it, unconvinced you made the right choice.
You have a habit of keeping several different-colored plastic bags on you and you use them to sort your inventory into categories. The green bag is reserved for 'the good stuff'.
You have a daughter on the outside who sometimes sends you postcards and letters. It's the only thing that still keeps you going.
You keep a single domino piece on you - the double six. You flip it whenever a decision feels too big.

You carry a cracked and broken Zippo lighter engraved with a monogram - your only memento of your childhood sweetheart who died in a car accident. You still reach for it out of habit whenever you light a cigarette, despite years having passed since it broke.

You were once trapped for three days under a collapsed building after an IED exploded on you during a previous mission in Iraq. You're paranoid it will happen again and you obsessively check the walls of any building you enter for structural integrity.

You used to have a best friend in the UNISG with whom you went on numerous missions. You came to the Zone together, but he stepped into an anomaly and died in the first week. You still have nightmares about seeing him lifted into the air and torn to pieces.
You have taken up origami in an attempt to stay sane in the Zone. You like folding empty cigarette packs into paper cranes and leaving them in unexpected places.

You proposed to your girlfriend a couple of days before leaving on your assignment to the Zone. She laughed at you, saying she needs stability and not a man who smells like gunpowder, regret and PTSD.

You were brought up by your mother to keep meticulous track of your income and expenses after your father got jailed for twenty years over fraud and tax evasion charges when you were eight years old. You still keep receipts of everything you buy and sell, despite there being no taxes or authority in the Zone.
You used to be a cinema projectionist when you were a teenager. You have a vast knowledge of movies and film trivia and enjoy talking about it - particularly the classics.

You keep a folded and worn photo of your ex-girlfriend's dog in an inside pocket. The ex-girlfriend was a cold-hearted bitch you're glad to see the back of, but her dog was the most endearing creature you've ever come across.

You came to the Zone with your two good friends who were fellow UNISG operatives. You've had to bury both at this point, and their ghosts still haunt you. You try to visit their graves on their birthdays, when you'll pour a drink on their grave and chainsmoke cigarettes all night recapping your past year.
You used to be a slaughterhouse worker as a teenager. Blood and smell don't bother you and hunting and butchering mutants comes naturally to you.
You have developed a slight limp in your right leg after a close encounter with a pseudodog. You're still not used to the constant dull pain.

Your ex-wife left with your daughter, who you haven't seen since she was eight. You send half your earnings to her in envelopes, hoping she follows your instructions in the enclosed letters to put the money away for an education and make better life decisions than you.

You've been in the Zone for several years. You can't remember the last time someone adressed you by your full given name, and your memories of the normal world are becoming hazy. You sometimes worry that you're losing touch with your old self and will never be able to go back to the normal world.

You have become obsessed with the myth of the Oasis, and you are determined to be the next person in the Zone to find it. You carry complex, nonsensical maps you have drawn that you claim will lead to it.
You are scared of being out at night in the Zone after a close encounter with a Poltergeist almost cost you your life.
You grew up dirt poor.

You are addicted to morphine. It started as a medical necessity after sustaining a minor combat injury in the Zone, but it quickly became your only comfort to deal with the mental stress of life in the Zone.

When you were still fairly fresh in the Zone you foolhardily tried to venture into the Red Forest. You were left gravely injured after stepping into an anomaly and would have died were it not for a random UNISG patrol passing by. Since then you've been extremely wary of pushing northward, and you're extremely uncomfortable whenever you're north of Rostok.
You give your firearms female names, and you sometimes talk to them out loud.
You keep a journal where you record written summaries of your adventures in the Zone. Sometimes you subconsciously mutter whatever you're currently writing down out loud.
Before joining the UNSIG you were an operative for the US Special Forces. You are affected by severe PTSD from clandestine operations in multiple war zones.
You are an active operative for the CIA on a collaborative deployment with the UNISG. Your mission is gathering intel on the Zone for the US intelligence agencies.
You were a US Marine before joining the UNISG, doing three tours in Iraq.

You were a medic for the US Marines before joining the UNISG. You still have nightmares about your best friend and fellow marine dying in your arms in Afghanistan after stepping on an IED. You failed to save him.
You used to work for the US PMC Triple Canopy before being recruited into the UNISG.
You joined the US Army to fund your education, but it turned out you were never made for school. You worked for several Private Military Companies in the US before being recruited by the UNISG.
You have a wife waiting for you outside of the Zone, in the normal world. You often worry she is cheating on you while you're in here.
You believe you are already dead and the Zone is actually Purgatory.
You suffer from severe claustrophobia after falling into a gravitational anomaly that held you crushed against a ceiling for two days before a blowout released you.
Your six-year-old daughter got diagnosed with a rare form of leukemia, and the prognosis is highly uncertain. You hope you'll finish your assignment in the Zone in time to see her again.

Your wife left you years ago and took your ten-year-old son and an eight-year-old daughter with her. She said you were married to your job and never present. You never told her of the exact work you do, and you never argued with her as you have always put your duty above all. You always carry a set of old pictures of your kids on you, and sometimes on lonely nights in the Zone you look at them and wonder if you made the right choices.
You witnessed a controller take over your squad's minds and force them to shoot each other. You survived by playing dead, but you can still feel the controller's whisper in your head.
You have come to believe the Zone is a living organism. Sometimes you throw vodka or cigarettes into anomalies as offerings, hoping to gain the favour of the Zone.
You accidentally shot your best friend during a firefight with the Monolith. You told everyone he was shot by a Monolith soldier, but the lie is eating you alive.
You are a recovering heroin addict who finds the constant danger of the Zone is the only thing that distracts you from the withdrawal cravings.
You are a self-proclaimed 'Zone philosopher' who writes bad poetry about radiation and emissions, forcing anyone who shares your campfire to critique it.
You are a heavy smoker with expensive taste. You are willing to pay exorbitant prices for a single carton of pristine, American cigarettes.
You are somewhat germophobic, which often proves a hindrance in the Zone. You spends hours scrubbing gore and mud off your gear every evening, terrified of infection.

You are paranoid about getting your mind taken over by a Controller after having heard the horror stories around campfires. You are always ingesting unhealthy amounts of psy-blockers, leaving you emotionally numb and unable to feel joy.

Your son died of a rare brain tumor at the age of seven. Since coming to the Zone you've learned of the mythical 'Wish Granter', and you refuse to accept the legends are fake. You're desperately searching for it in the hopes of ressurecting your son.

You are a hypochondriac who mistakes every cough for the Black Lung. You often ask those around you to confirm whether you exhibit symptoms for various diseases, and you spend all your money on unnecessary medkits.

Years of committing atrocities as a Spec Ops agent has left you filled with self-loathing and depression. You can't ever see yourself living a normal life again, and you secretly hope every assignment will be the one leading to your death.

Your last mission outside the Zone was as the leader of a strike team against a suspected terrorist cell in Serbia. Your indiscriminate approach led to multiple civilian casualties, a disciplinary hearing and a forced reassignment to the Zone. You still think the ends justify the means and resent your reassignment and everything about the Zone.

You grew up with an abusive father who was a drunkard that beat you and your mother. One night as a teenager you finally snapped and killed him in self-defence. You still struggle with authority figures and have an itchy trigger finger when shouted at.
You are addicted to the adrenaline of the Blowouts. While others hide, you stay near windows to watch the sky burn, feeling a perverse connection to the energy.

You carry the dogtags of every former travelling companion you've lost around your neck. When asked about it you refuse to elaborate, afraid that nobody would join you if they knew how many people died travelling by your side.
You are convinced that the crows in the Zone are spies for the C-Consciousness.
You are a pyromaniac who finds beauty in the 'Burner' anomalies. You have to restrain yourself from throwing bolts into them just to watch the flames.
You survived a Bloodsucker attack by hiding under the corpse of your squad leader. You can still smell his blood on your clothes, no matter how many times you wash them.

You were born with perfect pitch and spent some time working as a piano tuner as a teenager. The constant off-pitch humming of the anomalies in the Zone drives you into migraines that only vodka can dull.

You're deeply depressed, desperately looking for a purpose. You keep a bullet casing on a string around your neck, which you tell people is a lucky charm. In reality, it's the bullet you save for yourself as a 'last restort'. Sometimes in the evenings you fiddle with it in front of the campfire, and it gives you a strange kind of comfort.

Your father was a veterinarian and you spent some time being his assistant growing up. You feel a twisted sense of pity for the blind dogs and fleshes, seeing the suffering animals beneath the mutations.
You have a deep scar across your throat from a knife fight with a terrorist on an assignment years ago. You speak in a raspy whisper and hate having to repeat yourself.

Your previous assignment was as a sniper in Chechnya. Your kill count was in the hundreds before even entering the Zone, and you've never been able to make peace with the fact that your only talent is killing.
You believe that you are slowly turning into a mutant. You constantly check your skin for scales or extra hair, scratching until you bleed.

You have a habit of collecting the patches of dead Stalkers. You tell yourself it's to remember them, but deep down, seeing all the people you have outlived in the Zone gives you a strange kind of comfort.
You hear the voice of your dead wife in the psi-emissions. She screams at you for your failures, and sometimes you scream back.
You saw a vision in a localized temporal anomaly that looked like your own corpse rotting in a ditch. You are now convinced your death is pre-destined and inescapable.
You abandoned your squad to loot a valuable artifact while they were pinned down by Bandits. They all died, and you used the money to buy better gear, but you can't look at yourself in the mirror.
You carry a baby's rattle in your pocket. It belonged to the son you never got to meet because you were on an overseas assignment in Libya when he was born and died.
You have been on an assignment to research the true nature of the secret labs in the Zone. You know too much about what the Zone really is, and that knowledge terrifies you.
You are convinced that the Zone is a punishment from God and you are here to serve penance. You refuse to use painkillers when injured.
You have always had a keen interest in history. You relish being in the Zone as it is like a living museum for the fall of the Soviet Union.

You were close friends with an ISG squadmate you were deployed to the Zone alongside. One day during a psi-emission he didn't get to cover in time and you watched him turn into a zombie. You had to put him down, and you still see his confused, empty eyes every time you close yours.
You have a collection of suicide notes you found on bodies. You read them to remind yourself that giving up is the easy way out.
You are terrified of silence. You constantly hum, tap your fingers, or check your gear just to fill the void.

You used to be deeply religious and brought your Bible into the Zone for comfort. After having witnessed the horrors of the Zone first hand you have started questioning your faith, and you've started to HEAVILY annotate your Bible as you no longer think the message of mercy and a loving God is accurate.
You have a recurring dream that you are trapped in an anomaly, screaming for help, while your friends walk past you. This has led to you having severe abandonment issues.
You witnessed a faction war skirmish where both sides were wiped out by a single chimera. You realized then that politics in the Zone are meaningless.
You are saving up money to buy a vineyard in Italy and retire. It's a beautiful dream that you know deep down you will die before achieving.
You are a functioning alcoholic who fills your canteen with vodka instead of water. You claim it helps with the radiation, but really it just numbs the fear.

You have a phobia of the underground labs. The artificial lights and humming machinery remind you of the hospital where your daughter died, victim to a rare heart disease when she was only nine years old.
You formerly served in the British SAS. During a raid in Kabul, you breached the wrong room and eliminated a family having dinner; the silence of the debriefing room haunts you more than the screams.

You were an operator for the German KSK. You requested transfer to the UNISG because you started enjoying the violence too much, and you needed a place where your lethality was an asset, not a liability.
You spent ten years in the French Foreign Legion under a false name. The Zone is just another hostile environment, but you sometimes forget which name is your real one.
You were a sniper for the Canadian JTF2. You once spent three days lying in freezing mud waiting for a target that never showed up. The patience required for the Zone feels like a cruel joke.
You served in the Australian SASR. You are accustomed to harsh environments, but the fact that the very air in the Zone tries to kill you is a stress that is slowly breaking your composure.
You were a member of the US Navy SEALs involved in a botched extraction that left your team dead. You joined the UNISG because you have a death wish, but you're too professional to do it yourself.
You were an interrogator for the CIA at a black site. You know exactly how much pain a human can endure, and you see that same look of broken resignation in the eyes of the Stalkers you encounter.
You were part of the South African Special Forces Brigade. You carry a pouch of soil from your family farm, knowing that if you die here, your body will never return to it.
You served in the Israeli Shayetet 13. You are ruthlessly efficient, but the supernatural nature of the Zone challenges your secular worldview and keeps you awake at night.
You cut your teeth in the Brazilian BOPE battalion in the favelas. The gang violence in the streets was the perfect training ground for the chaotic violence of the Zone.
You are a ghost operative; your files were erased by the UN when you entered the Zone. If you die here, no one will mourn you because, officially, you haven't existed for three years.
You were forced to execute a civilian witness during a black op in South America. The memory of her pleading face overlays the faces of the rookies you are now ordered to eliminate in the Zone.
You used to be a family man, but after your son committed suicide, you volunteered for the most dangerous UN postings available. You are looking for a bullet with your name on it.
You are strictly following orders to retrieve samples, but you have secretly begun destroying the most dangerous ones. You believe mankind was not meant to have this power.

You were a combat medic in the Swedish SOG before being recruited into the UNISG. You treat the wounded with cold efficiency, but you have stopped learning your patients' names because they all die eventually.
You have developed an obsession with the intricate geometry of artifacts. You spend hours staring at them, convinced they hold a mathematical message from a higher power.

You were a pathfinder for the Italian 9th Parachute Assault Regiment before the UNISG recruited you. You pride yourself on navigation, but the shifting landscape of the Zone is making you question your own sanity.
You were part of a UN peacekeeping force in Rwanda that was ordered to stand down during the genocide. You joined the ISG to finally have the authorization to pull the trigger.
You accidentally killed a fellow ISG operative during a night raid due to a malfunctioning IFF tag. Command cleared you, but you still see his thermal signature in your nightmares.
You write regularly to your parents in Norway. You tell them you are an engineering consultant in Kyiv, a lie that becomes harder to maintain with every letter.
You are convinced that the UN is conducting unethical experiments on its own operatives in the Zone. You constantly check your food and water for tampering.
You keep a small, smooth stone from a river in your Colorado hometown. It is the only thing in your possession that isn't radioactive or designed to kill.
You served in the Dutch KCT before joining the UNISG. You are pragmatic and grounded, but seeing a fractured gravity anomaly defy the laws of physics shattered your understanding of the world.
You suffer from chronic phantom pain in a finger you lost to a mutant bite. The finger is gone, but it still itches when danger is near.
You have become desensitized to gore, eating your rations with bloody hands without a second thought. It disturbs the rookies, but you can't bring yourself to care.
You formerly served in the Spanish GOE. You are deeply religious, and you view the Zone as a literal manifestation of Hell on Earth that must be contained.
You carry a folded flag of your home country, Denmark, deep in your pack. It is a reminder of a clean, orderly world that feels like a fantasy compared to the Zone.
You were a demolitions expert in the Belgian SFG. You have an urge to just blow everything up, believing that the only way to fix the Zone is to crater it.
You hold a PhD in biology but joined the ISG as a field operator. You are specifically recording intel on the mutants in the Zone.

You were a counter-terrorism specialist in the Austrian Jagdkommando before joining the UNISG. You're used to dehumanizing targets to make the killing easier. You tell yourself every fresh-faced rookie Loner you kill is a terrorist, even though internally the guilt is starting to slowly build.

After your first mission inside an area with active psi-fields, you realized the numbing mental effects of psy-blockers. Since then you've started to ingest vast amounts of psy-blockers daily as a coping mechanism. You feel constantly emotionally numb and unable to feel joy or pleasure, but it does make the killing easier.

You accidentally walked into a radiation hotspot during your first week. You have been cleared for duty, but you are convinced the doctors were lying. You can feel the tumors growing, ticking time bombs in your lungs.
You formerly served in the New Zealand SAS. The lush, overgrown vegetation of the Zone mocks you; it looks alive, but everything here is dead or dying. It's making you homesick.
You keep a bullet that you dug out of your own leg during a mission deep in the center of the Zone. It is a reminder that you are not invincible, despite what your training says.

You were a heavy drinker before the Zone, but you stopped cold turkey upon arrival. You need your hands steady, but the withdrawal is taking longer than you thought it would and your hands are still a little shaky.
You are paranoid that your equipment is being sabotaged by a mole in the group. You disassemble and reassemble your rifle three times a day.

You served in the Finnish Utti Jaeger Regiment before joining the UNISG, doing most of your work within the arctic circle. You are still getting used to the greens and browns of the Zone, and you miss the clarity of targets being contrasted against white snow.
You have a deep scar on your face from a knife fight in a bar in Marseille. You tell people it was a mutant injury, because the truth — that you almost died over a spilled drink — is too pathetic.

You were a covert operative for the DGSE before being recruited into the UNISG. You are used to lies and deception, and you're still struggling with getting used to the cold unblinking reality that is life in the Zone.
You have a habit of talking to the dead bodies you loot, apologizing for taking their supplies. It's a way to hold onto a shred of humanity.
You have seen things in the X-Labs that you are not cleared to speak of. The knowledge is a heavy burden that makes you look at the world with cynical eyes.
You were a sniper who waited too long to take the shot on your previous assignment, resulting in civilian casualties. You're still burdened by the guilt of the lives lost by your hesitation.
You keep a small, leather-bound book of poetry. It contrasts sharply with your brutal profession, a secret reminder of the beauty that used to exist.
You have a deep mistrust of the scientists you are sent to protect. You view them as arrogant children playing with fire, and you hate cleaning up their messes.

You were a bomb disposal technician in Northern Ireland before the UNISG recruited you. The constant, invisible threat of anomalies reminds you of the old days, walking down a street waiting for a click.

You formerly worked for the NSA in cyber-warfare before joining the UNISG. You came to the Zone to secure hardware and extract information, but you're struggling with the analog, rusty technology of the Zone.

You were a competitive marksman in the Olympics before joining the military, your skill as a sniper eventually leading to the UNISG recruiting you. You treat combat as a sport to maintain your distance from the horror of it.
You served in the Norwegian FSK before joining the UNISG. You still miss the clean, cold air of the north.
You carry a photo of a woman you never married in an inside pocket. You regret prioritizing your career over her, and now that you are likely to die here, that regret is all you have.
You have a habit of sketching the mutants you encounter. It's a morbid hobby, but analyzing their anatomy helps you find their weak spots.
You formerly served in the Swiss ARD 10. You are neutral and professional, but the suffering of the stalkers in the Zone chips away at your detached exterior.
You are the longest-serving member of your current squad. Everyone else is a replacement, and you have stopped trying to make friends with soon-to-be ghosts.

You carry a drawing your nine-year-old sister made of you as a 'hero', which she gave you after you told her you were getting deployed on another mission. You can't even bring yourself to look at it anymore - nothing that you've done inside the Zone is the work of a 'hero'.

You used to be a heavy smoker, but you quit in the Zone because the glow of a cigarette tip gave away your position once, resulting in a sniper grazing your ear. You still crave nicotine constantly and miss smoking like nothing you've ever missed before, which means you're always in a bad mood.

After what you've seen in the Zone on your missions you've started to question what you and the ISG are doing here. You've become convinced Duty have the right idea, and every day you think about defecting to them and helping them in their cause to destroy the Zone for good.
